caption_original: What an honour! The New York Times released their 52 Places to Go in 2017, and Canada ranked... number ONE! We're welcoming people from across the globe to celebrate #Canada150 with us. With over 200 national parks, historic sites and marine conservation areas to visit #FREE, you're sure to find something spectacular!

caption_original: Hey #Toronto! Join us at MEC ’s downtown location this Saturday, Jan. 28 from 3 to 5 p.m. for the launch of the new National Geographic Guide to the National Parks of Canada. Be one of the first 25 people to stop by our booth to receive a free copy of the guide. Our mascot, #Parka, will also be stopping by from 4 to 4:30 p.m., and we’ll have FREE 2017 Parks Canada Discovery Passes to give away. See you there. #Canada150 #NatGeoParksCanada

caption_original:
A museum of a museum, did you know Banff Park Museum is a National Historic Site? The building itself is the largest and most elaborate example of the early phase of park design utilizing decorative cross-log construction. Built in 1903, it gives visitors a place to discover Banff National Park's #nature and #history! 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original: Despite its scary looks, the Wolffish is rarely aggressive! In fact, #wolffish are model parents that take special care of their eggs as they develop. They can be found in Canada's Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and unfortunately, some members of this family are considered #speciesatrisk. #NatureForAll #wildlifewednesday
caption_cleaned: Despite its scary looks, the Wolffish is rarely aggressive! In fact, are model parents that take special care of their eggs as they develop. They can be found in Canada's Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and unfortunately, some members of this family are considered .

caption_original: On January 20 1850, the HMS Investigator set sail in hopes of finding the lost #FranklinExpedition, and more importantly, the Northwest Passage. The Investigator was abandoned in 1853 when it became stuck in the ice of Mercy Bay.  In 2010, we discovered the HMS Investigator just north of #Aulavik National Park. Parks Canada NWT #OTD #TodayinHistory

caption_original:
It's time for #TriviaTuesday! This isolated post was a vital fur trade hub for more than 250 years... What is it called? #NHS100

ANSWER: It's York Factory National Historic Site in Manitoba! Between 1684 and its closing 273 years later in 1957, York Factory served as a trading post. From 1812 to the late 1850s, it was also the main entry point for European immigration to Western Canada.
caption_cleaned: It's time for ! This isolated post was a vital fur trade hub for more than years... What is it called? ANSWER: It's York Factory National Historic Site in Manitoba! Between and its closing years later in , York Factory served as a trading post. From to the late s, it was also the main entry point for European immigration to Western Canada.

caption_original:
Did you know the remaining structures at Jasper House were destroyed in 1909? A party of surveyors to the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway converted materials from the surviving cabin into a raft. It is now an archaeological site with few remaining vestiges of the past but a strong sense of #history. #JasperHouseNHS
